sen.j: 狩野 永岳（かのう えいがく、 寛政2年（1790年） - 慶応3年1月2日 (旧暦)（1867年2月6日））は、江戸時代後期に京都を中心に活躍した画家。
sen.e: Eigaku KANO (1790 - February 6, 1867) was a Kyoto-based painter active in the late Edo period.
Eigaku KANO (1790 - February 6, 1867) was a Kyoto-based painter who was active in the late Edo period.
Eigaku KANO (1790 - February 6, 1867) was a Kyoto-based painter who was active in the late Edo period.

sen.j: 京狩野家9代。
sen.e: The ninth generation head of the Kyo Kano (Kyoto branch of Kano school).
The ninth head of the Kyo Kano (Kyoto branch of Kano school).
The ninth head of the Kyo Kano (Kyoto branch of Kano school).

sen.j: 安土桃山時代桃山文化風の画風を基本に円山四条派や文人画、復古大和絵など様々な画風を取り入れ、低迷する京狩野家を再興した。
sen.e: Based on the painting style evocative of the Momoyama culture in the Azuchi-Momoyama period, Eigaku actively adopted various painting styles such as MARUYAMA Shijo school, literati painting and Revived Yamato-e (pure Japanese style painting) and succeeded to revive the Kyo Kano family which had been losing popularity and influence then.
sen.cmt: 安土桃山時代（の）桃山文化風→「の」が抜けていると思います。京狩野→Kyo KANO (狩野は苗字のため大文字）
sen.e: Based on the Momoyama painting style (luxurious, splendid and decorative style created during the Azuchi-Momoyama period), Eigaku actively adopted various painting styles such as MARUYAMA Shijo school, literati painting and Revived Yamato-e (reviving traditional Japanese style painting) and succeeded in reviving the Kyo Kano family which had lost popularity and influence then.
sen.cmt: ・「桃山風の画風」は補足説明要と判断しました。・表現の修正
sen.e: Based on the Momoyama painting style (luxurious, splendid and decorative style created during the Azuchi-Momoyama period), Eigaku actively adopted various painting styles such as MARUYAMA Shijo school, literati painting and Revived Yamato-e (reviving traditional Japanese style painting) and succeeded in reviving the Kyo Kano family which had lost popularity and influence then.

sen.j: 永岳（永嶽）は諱。
sen.e: Eigaku (永岳 or永嶽) was his imina (real name).
Eigaku (永岳 or永嶽) was his imina (real name).
Eigaku (永岳 or永嶽) was his imina (real name).

sen.j: 初名は泰助、字を公嶺。
sen.e: His original name was Yasusuke and his azana (nickname) Korei, respectively.
sen.cmt: 泰助＝Yasusuke 正式な読みが確認できませんでした。
sen.e: His original name was Yasusuke and his azana (nickname) Korei.
sen.cmt: respectively は不要と判断しました。
sen.e: His original name was Yasusuke and his azana (nickname) Korei.

sen.j: 山梁、晩翠、脱庵なと号 (称号)した。
sen.e: His go (pen name) included Sanryo, Bansui and Datsuan.
sen.cmt: 読みは「日本美術シソーラスＤＢ（筑波大学）」によります。http://www.tulips.tsukuba.ac.jp/jart/mokuji/index.html
sen.e: His go (pen name) included Sanryo, Bansui and Datsuan.
His go (pen name) included Sanryo, Bansui and Datsuan.

sen.j: 代々の通称、縫殿助（ぬいのすけ）を名乗った。
sen.e: He also called himself Nuinosuke that was a common name used by the head of the Kyo Kano family in generations.
He also called himself Nuinosuke that was a common name used by the heads of the Kyo Kano family for generations.
He also called himself Nuinosuke that was a common name used by the heads of the Kyo Kano family for generations.

sen.j: 京都の人。
sen.e: He was born and raised in Kyoto.
sen.cmt: 「京都の人」→説明的に「京都で生まれ育った」としました。
sen.e: He was born and raised in Kyoto.
He was born and raised in Kyoto.

sen.j: 略伝
sen.e: Brief Biography
Brief Biography
Brief Biography

sen.j: 父は京狩野の絵師影山洞玉（後の狩野永章）。
sen.e: Eigaku's father was Dogyoku KAGEYAMA (later Eisho KANO), who was a painter of Kyo Kano school.
Eigaku's father was Dogyoku KAGEYAMA (later Eisho KANO), who was a painter of Kyo Kano school.
Eigaku's father was Dogyoku KAGEYAMA (later Eisho KANO), who was a painter of Kyo Kano school.

sen.j: 早くに才能を見いだされ京狩野8代狩野永俊の養子となり、文化 (元号)13年（1816年）永俊が没すると27歳で家督を継いだ。
sen.e: Eigaku excelled in painting since his early age and Eishun KANO, eighth head of Kyo KANO, discovered his talent and adopted him, and later Eigaku succeeded as the family head at the age of 27 when Eishun died in 1816.
Eishun KANO, the eighth head of Kyo Kano, who discovered a young Eigaku's talent, adopted him and Eigaku took over as the family head at the age of 27 when Eishun died in 1816.
Eishun KANO, the eighth head of Kyo Kano, who discovered a young Eigaku's talent, adopted him and Eigaku took over as the family head at the age of 27 when Eishun died in 1816.

sen.j: 初代狩野山楽の末裔であることを誇りとし、箱書きや落款に「山楽九世孫」としたためている。
sen.e: He was proud of being a descendant of Sanraku KANO and signed and sealed on his paintings or autographed on the boxes containing artwork as "Sanraku kyusei mago" (the ninth generation of Sanraku).

He was so proud of being a descendant of Sanraku KANO that he signed and sealed on his paintings or autographed on the boxes containing artwork as 'Sanraku kyusei mago' (the ninth generation of Sanraku).

He was so proud of being a descendant of Sanraku KANO that he signed and sealed on his paintings or autographed on the boxes containing artwork as 'Sanraku kyusei mago' (the ninth generation of Sanraku).

sen.j: 山楽や狩野山雪の画を熱心に学び、桃山風の画風を基本とした。
sen.e: Eigaku earnestly studied the paintings of Sanraku and Sansetsu KANO and his painting was based on the painting style of the Momoyama period.
Eigaku earnestly studied the paintings of Sanraku and Sansetsu KANO, taking the Momoyama painting style as a base for his painting.
Eigaku earnestly studied the paintings of Sanraku and Sansetsu KANO, taking the Momoyama painting style as a base for his painting.

sen.j: その上で、当時京都で人気を博していた四条派の画風を積極的にとり入れている。
sen.e: In addition, he actively adopted the painting style of Shijo school that was popular in Kyoto at that time.
In addition, he actively adopted the painting style of Shijo school that was popular in Kyoto at that time.
In addition, he actively adopted the painting style of Shijo school that was popular in Kyoto at that time.

sen.j: この他にも江戸中期に来日した沈南蘋の流れを汲む長崎派や、谷文晁によって広まった北宗画や文人画、俵屋宗達・尾形光琳の装飾的な琳派、甥にあたる冷泉為恭から復古大和絵を直接学んだ。
sen.e: He also learned painting technique such as Nagasaki school, a painting school influenced by Shen Nanpin who came to Japan in the middle of the Edo period, Hokuso-ga (painting style originating in the Northern Sung Dynasty), literali painting which became popular with Buncho TANI, decorative Rinpa style by Sotatsu TAWARAYA and Korin OGATA, and Revived Yamato-e which he learned directly from his nephew, Tameyasu REIZEI.
sen.cmt: 沈南蘋 英語名 Shen Nanpinを使用しました。日本語読みでは Chin Nanpin。
sen.e: Furthermore, his painting style was influenced by Nagasaki school, a painting school influenced by Shen Nanpin who came to Japan in the middle of the Edo period, Hokusoga (the northern school of Chinese painting) and literati painting spread by Buncho TANI, decorative Rinpa style by Sotatsu TAWARAYA and Korin OGATA, Revived Yamato-e learned directly from his nephew, Tameyasu REIZEI.
sen.cmt: ・表現の修正・「北宗画」は定訳を採用しました。
sen.e: Furthermore, his painting style was influenced by Nagasaki school, a painting school influenced by Shen Nanpin who came to Japan in the middle of the Edo period, Hokusoga (the northern school of Chinese painting) and literati painting spread by Buncho TANI, decorative Rinpa style by Sotatsu TAWARAYA and Korin OGATA, Revived Yamato-e learned directly from his nephew, Tameyasu REIZEI.

sen.j: このように様々な画風を貪欲に吸収し自家薬籠中の物とした。
sen.e: In this way he avidly adopted various painting styles and absorbed them into his own painting style.
In this way he avidly adopted various painting styles to blend them with his own painting style.
In this way he avidly adopted various painting styles to blend them with his own painting style.

sen.j: 京狩野家は代々九条家と関係が深く、永岳33歳の時、画を好む九条尚忠の家来となった。
sen.e: The Kyo Kano family had been in a close relationship with the Kujo family for generations, and when Eigaku was 33 years old he served Hisatada KUJO who liked painting.
The Kyo Kano family had been in a close relationship with the Kujo family for generations, and when Eigaku was 33 years old, he served Hisatada KUJO who liked painting.
sen.cmt: 33 years old の直後に、コンマを加えました。
sen.e: The Kyo Kano family had been in a close relationship with the Kujo family for generations, and when Eigaku was 33 years old, he served Hisatada KUJO who liked painting.

sen.j: 嘉永6年（1853年）、尚忠が左大臣の公務で江戸に下ったとき、これに同行し富士山を実見し「富士百幅」を描いている。
sen.e: In 1853, Eigaku accompanied Hisatada to go to Edo on an official assignment as sadaijin (the Minister of the Left) and saw Mt. Fuji, which inspired him to paint "Fuji Hyakkei" (one hundred paintings of Mt. Fuji).
In 1853, Eigaku accompanied Hisatada on his official visit to Edo as sadaijin (Minister of the Left) and saw Mt. Fuji, which inspired him to paint 'Fuji Hyappuku' (one hundred paintings of Mt. Fuji).
sen.cmt: ・表現の修正・「富士百幅」の読みを修正しました（静岡県立美術館回答）。
sen.e: In 1853, Eigaku accompanied Hisatada on his official visit to Edo as sadaijin (Minister of the Left) and saw Mt. Fuji, which inspired him to paint 'Fuji Hyappuku' (one hundred paintings of Mt. Fuji).

sen.j: 永岳の代になって京狩野は紀州徳川家と彦根藩の御用絵師も務めるようになった。
sen.e: When Eigaku was the family head, the Kyo Kano also served as an official painter of Kishu TOKUGAWA family and the Hikone domain.
When Eigaku was the family head, the Kyo Kano also served as an official painter of Kishu Tokugawa family and the Hikone domain.
sen.cmt: 「紀州徳川家」は個人名ではないので、通常表記にしました。
sen.e: When Eigaku was the family head, the Kyo Kano also served as an official painter of Kishu Tokugawa family and the Hikone domain.

sen.j: 井伊家の菩堤寺である清涼寺に伝わる井伊直弼の肖像画は永岳が画いたとされる。
sen.e: The portrait of Naosuke II extant at Seiryo-ji Temple, II's family temple, was assumedly painted by Eigaku.
The portrait of Naosuke II housed at Seiryo-ji Temple, the family temple of the Ii, was assumedly painted by Eigaku.
The portrait of Naosuke II housed at Seiryo-ji Temple, the family temple of the Ii, was assumedly painted by Eigaku.

sen.j: 57歳にして禁裏（朝廷）御絵師御次席となってから落款に「金門画史」・「金門画院第一史」と記すこともあった。
sen.e: After Eigaku became deputy official court painter at the age of 57, he sometimes signed and sealed as "kinmon gashi" ('金門画史') or "kinmon gain daiichishi" ('金門画院第一史').
After Eigaku became the deputy official court painter at the age of 57, he sometimes signed and sealed as 'kinmon gashi' ('金門画史') or 'kinmon gain daiichishi' ('金門画院第一史').
sen.cmt: ・「金門画史」は「きんもんえし」の可能性もあります。・「金門画院・・・」は翻訳を採用しました。
sen.e: After Eigaku became the deputy official court painter at the age of 57, he sometimes signed and sealed as 'kinmon gashi' ('金門画史') or 'kinmon gain daiichishi' ('金門画院第一史').

sen.j: 66歳のとき禁裏の安政度造営が行われ多くの障壁画の制作にあたっている。
sen.e: In the rebuilding of Kyoto Imperial Palace at Ansei era when he was 66 years old, he created many paintings on sliding doors or screens.
When he was 66 years old, he participated in the rebuilding of Kyoro Imperial Palace at Ansei period to create many wall paintings at the palace
sen.cmt: ・表現の修正・「障壁画」は定訳を採用しました。
sen.e: When he was 66 years old, he participated in the rebuilding of Kyoro Imperial Palace at Ansei period to create many wall paintings at the palace

sen.j: 臨済宗妙心寺には永岳の作品が多く残り、とりわけ隣華院客殿障壁画は永岳の代表作といえる。
sen.e: Many Eigaku's works are extant in Rinzai Sect Myoshin-ji Temple, among which the painting on sliding doors of the reception hall in Rinkain is considered his masterpiece.
Many Eigaku's works are housed in Rinzai Sect Myoshin-ji Temple, among which works the wall painting of the reception hall in Rinka-in Temple is considered to be his masterpiece.
Many Eigaku's works are housed in Rinzai Sect Myoshin-ji Temple, among which works the wall painting of the reception hall in Rinka-in Temple is considered to be his masterpiece.

sen.j: 同じく臨済宗大徳寺にも頂相など多数の作品が残されている。
sen.e: Rinzai Sect Daitoku-ji Temple also has many Eigaku's works such as choso (portraits of high ranking Zen monks).
Rinzai Sect Daitoku-ji Temple also has many Eigaku's works such as choso (portraits of high ranking Zen monks).
Rinzai Sect Daitoku-ji Temple also has many Eigaku's works such as choso (portraits of high ranking Zen monks).

sen.j: 東本願寺にも大障壁画を手掛けたがのちに焼失した。
sen.e: He also created a large wall painting at Higashi Hongan-ji Temple, which was later destroyed in a fire.
He also created a large wall painting at Higashi Hongan-ji Temple, but it was later destroyed in a fire.
sen.cmt: 翻訳では焼失したのは東本願寺となるので、修正しました。
sen.e: He also created a large wall painting at Higashi Hongan-ji Temple, but it was later destroyed in a fire.

sen.j: 本願寺を通じて地方の別院にも永岳の作品が多数見られる。
sen.e: Many Eiraku's paintings were extant at local branch temples through Hongan-ji Temple network.
Many Eiraku's paintings are also housed in local branch temples of Hongan-ji Temple.
sen.cmt: 「本願寺を通じて地方の別院」は「本願寺の別院」としました。
sen.e: Many Eiraku's paintings are also housed in local branch temples of Hongan-ji Temple.

sen.j: この他にも永岳は多くパトロンをもち、京都はいうに及ばず長浜や飛騨高山にも足を伸ばし、富商や富農の求めに応じて絵を画いた。
sen.e: In addition, Eigaku, who had many patrons, did not confine his artistic activities to Kyoto but extended to as far as Nagahama or Hida-Takayama and painted there upon the wealthy merchants or farmers' request.
In addition, Eigaku, who had many patrons, expanded his artistic activities to Nagahama or Hida and painted there upon the wealthy merchants' or farmer's request.
sen.cmt: 「長浜や飛騨高山にも足を伸ばし」だけで「京都はいうに及ばず」は表現されているので、「京都は・・・」は訳出しませんでした。
sen.e: In addition, Eigaku, who had many patrons, expanded his artistic activities to Nagahama or Hida and painted there upon the wealthy merchants' or farmer's request.

sen.j: 禁裏の御用絵師とはいえ、永岳が家督を継いだ頃の京狩野派は、土佐派や鶴沢派の後塵を拝し不遇な立場にあった。
sen.e: When Eigaku succeeded as the family head, Kyo Kano was experiencing a difficult time, losing its popularity and falling behind the Tosa school and the Tsurusawa school, even though Kyo Kano served as official painter at the Imperial Palace.
When Eigaku took over as the family head, Kyo Kano, serving as the official painter at the Imperial Palace, was playing second fiddle to the Tosa school and the Tsurusawa school.
sen.cmt: 表現を簡略にしました。
sen.e: When Eigaku took over as the family head, Kyo Kano, serving as the official painter at the Imperial Palace, was playing second fiddle to the Tosa school and the Tsurusawa school.

sen.j: なおかつ江戸後期には伝統的な画派は勢力を弱め、特色を持った新興の画派が台頭していた。
sen.e: Besides, the traditional painting schools were losing their momentum and the new painting schools with distinctive characters had been emerging in the late Edo period.
Besides, the traditional painting schools were losing their momentum and the new painting schools with distinctive characters were emerging in the late Edo period instead.
Besides, the traditional painting schools were losing their momentum and the new painting schools with distinctive characters were emerging in the late Edo period instead.

sen.j: 永岳は生き残りを掛け京狩野の伝統を革新させ、特色を打ち出すことに成功する。
sen.e: Eigaku tried to revolutionalize the traditional painting style of Kyo Kano for its survival and succeeded to appeal its own distinctive style.
Eigaku tried to revolutionize the traditional painting style of Kyo Kano for its survival and succeeded in establishing its own distinctive style.
Eigaku tried to revolutionize the traditional painting style of Kyo Kano for its survival and succeeded in establishing its own distinctive style.

sen.j: 長寿であったことも幸いして京都画壇では重鎮として扱われた。
sen.e: He lived long and was treated as a leading figure in Kyoto art circle partially thanks to his longevity.
He was treated as a leading figure in Kyoto art world thanks partly to his longevity.
He was treated as a leading figure in Kyoto art world thanks partly to his longevity.

sen.j: 享年79。
sen.e: Eigaku died at the age of 79.
Eigaku died at the age of 79.
Eigaku died at the age of 79.

sen.j: 養子の狩野永祥が10代を相続。
sen.e: His adopted son, Eisho succeeded him to become the tenth family head.
His adopted son, Eisho succeeded him to become the tenth family head.
His adopted son, Eisho succeeded him to become the tenth family head.

sen.j: 門弟に長野祐親などがいる。
sen.e: Sukechika NAGANO was one of Eigaku's pupils.
Sukechika NAGANO was one of Eigaku's pupils.
Sukechika NAGANO was one of Eigaku's pupils.

sen.j: そのほかに岩国藩御用絵師の佐藤丹治、土佐藩の河田小龍、京焼の永楽保全なども永岳に画を習ったという。
sen.e: It is said that Tanji SATO, an official painter of the Iwakuni domain, Shoryu KAWADA of the Tosa domain and Hozen EIRAKU of Kyo yaki (Kyoto style ceramic art) also studied painting under Eigakuku.
It is said that Tanji SATO, an official painter of the Iwakuni domain, Shoryu KAWADA of the Tosa domain and Hozen EIRAKU of Kyo yaki (Kyoto style ceramic art) also studied painting under Eigaku.
It is said that Tanji SATO, an official painter of the Iwakuni domain, Shoryu KAWADA of the Tosa domain and Hozen EIRAKU of Kyo yaki (Kyoto style ceramic art) also studied painting under Eigaku.
